abstract: Led by the Fed, five central banks announced an aggressive infusion of capital into the banking system, hoping to ease the credit crunch.
snippet: Led by the Fed, five central banks announced an aggressive infusion of capital into the banking system, hoping to ease the credit crunch.
lead_paragraph: A day after the Federal Reserve disappointed investors with a modest cut in interest rates, central banks in North America and Europe on Wednesday announced the most aggressive infusion of capital into the banking system since the terrorist attacks of September 2001.

headline.main: Central Bankers to Lend Billions in Credit Crisis
headline.print_headline: CENTRAL BANKERS TO LEND BILLIONS IN CREDIT CRISIS

byline.original: By Vikas Bajaj and Floyd Norris

abstract: The Bank of America Corporation, the Wachovia Corporation and PNC Financial Services Group said on Wednesday that losses tied to bad debt would be worse than expected.
snippet: The Bank of America Corporation, the Wachovia Corporation and PNC Financial Services Group said on Wednesday that losses tied to bad debt would be worse than expected.
lead_paragraph: The Bank of America Corporation, the Wachovia Corporation and PNC Financial Services Group said on Wednesday that losses tied to bad debt would be worse than expected, the latest indication that the credit markets are not returning to normal.

headline.main: 3 Big Banks See No Relief as Write-Offs Mount Up
headline.print_headline: 3 Big Banks See No Relief As Write-Offs Mount Up

abstract: Bank of America, Wachovia and the PNC Financial Services Group said on Wednesday that losses tied to bad debt would be worse than expected, the latest indication that the credit markets are not returning to normal.
lead_paragraph: Bank of America, Wachovia and the PNC Financial Services Group said on Wednesday that losses tied to bad debt would be worse than expected, the latest indication that the credit markets are not returning to normal.

headline.main: 3 Big Banks See No Relief as Write-Offs Mount
